Export controls have been a part of U.S. policy for almost a century, with a shift towards extensive peacetime regulations after WWII. The Export Control Act of 1949 formalized the need for an extensive peacetime export control system, focusing on the Soviet-Bloc countries during the Cold War. It identified three reasons for imposing export controls: short-supply controls to prevent the export of scarce goods, foreign policy controls to promote foreign policy objectives, and national security controls to address security threats. The 1949 Export Control Act established short-supply, foreign policy, and national security controls to prevent the export of scarce goods, promote foreign policy objectives, and address security threats. This included controlling items related to regional stability, human rights, anti-terrorism, missile technology, and chemical and biological warfare. The Export Control Act of 1949 established security controls to restrict the export of goods and technology that could enhance the military capability of countries threatening US national security. CoCom was created as a multilateral counterpart to regulate critical technology transfers among NATO allies. The Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls (CoCom) was established in 1949 to regulate critical technology transfers among NATO allies. The Export Control Act was renewed multiple times with high restrictions until the U.S.-Soviet era of "detente" in the late 1960s led to a reexamination and revision of the export control system. The Export Administration Act of 1969 replaced the near-embargo characteristic of the Export Control Act of 1949, reflecting a shift towards less restrictive policies. The Export Administration Act of 1969 replaced the strict export controls of the 1949 Export Control Act, reflecting a trend towards liberalization. Subsequent renewals in 1974 and 1977 continued this shift, with a comprehensive rewrite in 1979 forming the basis of the current export control system.
